title: Defining original reporting is challenging, says Google search boss
text:
Mr Gomes said that agreeing on the definition of original reporting could be difficult when trying to balance the need for up-to-date content – for example, a rival media organisation adding to an original story by following up with new information that was not part of the original report.

"There’s some complicated trade-offs here as to what is the right thing that users want to see, while also making sure that we give due prominence to the original reporting wherever that makes sense," he said.

The ACCC noted in its final report, released in July, that digital platforms that offered search functions did not reward media companies for original content or breaking news stories, compared with companies that copied content.

We do bring information to a lot of people – questions about that is a natural part of playing this role. — Ben Gomes, Google vice-president of search

The regulator noted numerous examples of news content that had taken a large amount of resources to publish being copied within hours by rivals without the financial or time outlay. It said consumers often found it difficult to identify where the original report came from and this was hurting the ability to monetise original reporting.

"As such, media organisations that republish articles are able to compete effectively for online audiences with the content originators, who may have invested significantly in uncovering and/or producing the story," the ACCC said.

"This may potentially reduce the incentives for news media businesses to invest in investigative journalism and other news content that is costly to produce."

Google's changes come as the federal government prepares its full response to the ACCC's report.

Advertisement

Google came out strongly against two recommendations –a code of conduct to govern its business dealings with media companies and being forced to offer users of its mobile operating system Android a choice for their default search engine in their browsers.

The ACCC also recommended that a branch be established within the commission to monitor and investigate algorithms used by companies such as Google and Facebook.

'Details do matter'

Mr Gomes would not say whether Google supported regulatory oversight of its algorithms.

"We have to see what form it takes in more detail. I think it’s hard to comment in the abstract on these things because the details do matter ... we have a process and system which is very much geared towards making changes and adjusting search," he said.

The methodology around search and changes to the algorithms were geared towards getting good-quality search results and doing the right things by users, he said.

"That’s what aligned with our long-term interest, I think it’s aligned with users and, if anybody looks at that process in more detail, I think that’s what would be evident," Mr Gomes said.

"We do bring information to a lot of people – questions about that is a natural part of playing this role. I see that as just a natural part of the role we play in getting information to people."

The reporter travelled to California courtesy of Google
description: Google has faced heavy criticism from all corners of the media for the way it brings up news in its Google Search and Google News rankings.
